title: Does quark–gluon plasma make free-roaming single quarks? - Quora

response.answer_text: A.: No. Quarks are fermions and can be made (created) only in quark-antiquark pairs. In turn, “[quark-gluon plasma] state is thought to consist of asymptotically free strong-interacting quarks and gluons,…” says the Wikipedia entry on quark–gluon plasma. Note: “asymptotically free” is not “free-roaming.”

Quark gluon plasma, according to the current understanding, behaves like a perfect fluid, that is quarks and gluons move without any viscosity effects but are manifesting collective effects like vorticity. In this sense single quarks are not free-roaming particles of this special liquid reaching temperature hundred thousands higher than that of the Sun’s core. Heavy ions and quark-gluon plasma
